name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Law and Order

transcript.content: Aristotle once observed, law is order and good law is good order. A seemingly simple concept, but the realities of making those good laws and enforcing them have troubled society since time immemorial. From community service to capital punishment, everyone has a view on how we protect the innocent and punish the guilty. Is one man's law another man's tyranny? Is justice available to all? Does prison work? Should we lock up law breakers and throw away the key? Or does that fail to address the root causes of crime? To discuss these questions and more, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, award winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington. Look at that fucking head.
Right.
So, Karl, law and order.
I'm not that interested in it to be honest.
What do you mean?
I've got no interest in law and order whatsoever. It's not part of my life. That's the problem. You keep picking topics that don't buzz me.
Of course they do.
They don't.
Well, let's talk about this. Let's talk about this.
You're a man quite obsessed with law and order.
Based on what?

Well, law and order is basically to protect the innocent, isn't it? I mean, when we think of law and order, we usually think of crime and punishment, but it's all about protect our person. We have the right to walk the streets without getting mugged when someone wrongs us. We want justice. It's fundamental. And you do. You were sitting in your old flat in London in front of me every day that you wanted to go downstairs and smack their heads in for being late and shouting around and being drunk, and you could hear it. You wanted some justice.
Yeah, but nothing would have happened if I called someone up and said, there's people doing noise pollution, even though there's a law for noise pollution now, it's not really taken seriously, is it?
But you are concerned with law and order.
No, but there's no point.
You wanted your rights. And you ended up moving. He's moved here now. He's moved to lovely sunny Hampstead, just down the road from us. So you're having a better life.
I shouldn't have to move because of some noisy people?
No, you shouldn't, but I'm saying you were stressed-
No one cares though.
-and you wanted justice, but you thought you couldn't get justice, so you moved away which is-
So I dealt with it in my way.
Yeah.
I hated them because they didn't care about anyone else.
Exactly.
The police wouldn't get involved. There's other people who live around there who had to put up with it. No one cared.
So what did it feel like every night when you were trying to watch telly and it's hot and you got the window open? All yeah.

You could just hear stuff it's that thing of you get a lot of tourists in London, so they talk. And it's not even as if you can listen into what they say and have a view on their opinion, because they're foreign.
Would that be entertaining for you.
Well, yeah, because if you can hear what people are saying. You're going "Oh yeah that's a good point"
"Switch the tele off" [laughing] that's a good point?
I don't want to hear anyone talking.

I'll tell you what, I really feel sorry for people with like, neighbours from hell because I'm not saying it's just fine, but I can see why people go mental with someone when they're bullied or constantly harassed and no one cares. And when you can't go to the police, you can't go to police and go "there's a bloke next door, he's got his tele on too loud. He's always pissed. He's shouting about. If you don't do something, I'm going to go around there and crack his head in. You'd be the one that...
Your own fault for living in Central London.
Well, not really, because it wasn't always like that. I've been there years, and all of a sudden, you know, Goodfellas turn up
Steve laughs
Sat down there, making a racket... What can you say to them? You call down, they can't hear the phone ringing...
Could I just say, 'Goodfellas' wasn't a pizza joint?
No
He called the loud people that because he thought they were gangsters-
Right. Sure.
'Cause they did what they wanted, and sat outside.
Sure. Yeah.
But it's louder... I think it is louder abroad, than it is here. Whenever I go away on holiday, I always notice that it's always a couple of decibels higher.
Really?
Always. Like the sound of bird noises and that, are louder abroad-
Steve laughs
-Because they're trying to get above the noise of the noisy people.
No, that's not true!

They are! When I was in... Where was I? Menorca or something? It was like... lying there, if it wasn't a noisy local, it was the people in the villa next door. If it's not them, they suddenly collected the bottles from the bottle bank... That's a nice noise when you just relaxing! The bottle bank. Pop that there, where the villa is! So that was a racket. There was just so much noise...
Animals, creatures...
You can't escape- It's the one thing you can't escape, noise. Your ears never turn off.
No.
They're always there.
But I've told you before, wear earplugs if you have to.
I don't like it.
But he says he can hear the sound of his own heart.
Well, there's always a sound. Like your eyes, you can close them. My eyes close all the time when--
They keep, it's called blinking.
(laughs) Yeah
If I don't like the look of something-- I don't like the look of something, they close before even I've thought about if I want to see it or not.
Steve & Ricky laugh
What do you mean exactly?
I just mean if I see something on the telly, or like one of those casualty programs or something
Yeah
It's like my eyes know that I'm not going to like the look of it.
No no no no. No no no.
So they close quicker. Me ears, they seem to be interested in everything.
Ricky & Steve laugh
Even though I'm not.
(laughs) No! You can't close your ears! You can't!
That's what I'm saying.
Exactly, yeah. You can't-- You can never--
I love the idea that your eyes are closing when you want-- "I was watching that! What are you doing, eyes?!".
Have your eyes ever closed something that you're--
"I was enjoying that!"
No. They normally get it right.
(laughs) "They normally get it right"

Your eyes aren't making decisions! You make the decision! You turn away because you don't like seeing something. You don't turn away, and then you're going "What was that?" And your eyes are going: "You don't want to know! You do not want to know, Karl."
I'm just saying anyway.
"Hmmm, lovely pairs of tits here!" "Ohh, what?!"
I just mean... noise pollution is the one thing you can't escape.

It seems to me, from what you said so far, is that these things happen to you and you feel wronged, but you either want to close your eyes and ears so you can't tell it's happening, but it's carrying on or move away from it. So you're not a victim anymore, but it's carrying on. But the thing about law and order is, you don't have to take it. You don't have to walk away. You can do something about it. You can combat being wronged. And I suppose we associate that with justice. It's not just punishment or retribution. It's justice you want to know that you're valued.

Well, this is a big issue, isn't it, Rick? Is... is one life more important than another? If you've transgressed in a terrible way -you've murdered or raped, whatever- and I'm gonna say I'm going to put you to death because you do not belong in this society, you are too transgressive... Why is that wrong? Why is that morally wrong thing to do, Karl?

Well, this is an interesting argument, isn't it? Whether capital punishment-- Now, I don't agree with execution. State execution of someone -whatever they've done- for many reasons, but the main one is: I don't think you can have a state that shows that sort of violence against the individual, whatever they've done, and expect people to accept the very code and morality of treating people equally and not showing violence towards them.
Karl, where's your stand on the tricky issue of capital punishment. You've given it some serious thought, I imagine.
So what you're asking me, like, should he be on death row?
Well, should someone flip the switch, send him to his death in the electric chair?
Karl thinks for about 8 seconds
...Yeah...
Steve laughs
That was the least considerate...
Yeah, yeah

I mean, I saw a little bit of flicker behind the eyes... I don't know what-- Just take us through the mental process that you arrived at the "yes" with there. So you've been-- Because there was a quite brief gap there.
I just was thinking... it's not a nice job if you work in there and you got to flick the switch.
Alright.
But I was wondering if it's possible to just do it so it's linked up to someone's switch.
Steve laughs
What do you mean?
When they put the lights on or something.
Steve & Ricky laugh

So it's like sometime tonight when the sun goes down and people start putting the lights on in their house, it could happen. But we don't know what household-- they might be away on holiday. So you might get an extra two weeks. But at least that way... Because for me--
Well... It's funny you say that.
This is not-- The question I asked was whether- We were talking about the morality of whether you put someone to death.
But he was thinking about-
He was thinking literally the practicality of flipping the switch.

Well, no, I think that you're... Aren't you talking about the integrity of the person who knows or knows not, that they put someone to death, like a firing squad. Like what they used to do sometimes in the First World War when they had six riflemen, but
Only one with the bullet.
Five were blanks and what had the-- And no one knew...
If they were the person that killed them.
Yeah.
So my point is, you do agree that someone should be put to death for a terrible crime, do you?

You've got to have something there to stop them people who don't care, haven't you? Nature has done it in a way, with bees. They've gone with "We'll give you a weapon, but if you use it, you die." And that's like the bee. So they're worried they're going to go "I'm not gonna do it"
Well that's what we were doing, weren't we? We have people saying "One, you can't do that." That's step one, here's the law. "Don't do it!"
Yeah. But there's a lot of people who are going "I'm not bothered about the law. I'm not bothered about annoying people."
Yeah, that's true.
So for them, at the end of the scale, you've got the chair and you stick the wires on their head and we'll fry your head. And they go "Oh, God. I don't want that".

That-that-that-that doesn't always work does it? With-with being put to death, because as a deterrent, most of the crimes aren't just crimes of gain with that. Some of them are crimes of passion, where a deterrent doesn't count because you see red and you go crazy and you're angry and you kill someone. I-I think a lot of those crimes, the deterrent isn't relevant. You know? Things like armed robbery, maybe, where it's a risk, what can I get versus what my crime -- maybe then it might be a deterrent. But then, of course, if you start to get a capital punishment for crimes that aren't murdering someone, then that thing brings in, you might as well murder them, because then you've got more chance of getting away with it. So it's very delicate what you make people be killed for, um.
You've made an interesting and reasoned argument there, Rick. I'm looking forward to hearing the Rapost.
Right. When I was younger, I used to nick Mars bars.
Ricky and Steve giggle
Okay.
All right? Now, I did that, then, and I knew that even if I get caught, what's the worst that's going to happen?
Yeah.
It's not gonna -- I'm not going to go to prison over that, but it was worth nicking because a Mars bar they were like 45 pence.
Sure.
When you're a kid, you can get a lot of chewing nuts for that.
Chewing nuts?
I don't know what he is talking about.
Yeah they are like caramel covered in chocolate, last ages, quite hard.
Oh, I know. Yeah, you suck the chocolate off and then you got to chew-
Caramel
-them until they're -- yeah I know yeah.
Now, I could afford them at ten pence a bag they're -- they'd last me sort of a morning. Umm, a Mars bar was a proper treat. There's a lot going on in there.
Yeah.
A lot of chocolate, a lot of caramel.
Yeah.
Like for I say 45 pence.
Yeah.
So to me --
So that was like an advert that went wrong just at the end.
Steve laughs

They started off good. They go, this guy's good -- he's uh -- Yeah get on there. "Mars bars a lot in it", - oh good, keep going. Yeah. - "It's got caramel." - Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah - "but it's 45 pence, which is too fucking much. So fucking nick it you cunt."
But, I was younger, that was worth a risk because I knew that I'd be getting something worth 45 pence-
Yeah
-for free.
You weren't going to get the electric chair.
And I wasn't going to get done. So the stakes were high. The risk were low.
No, wait wait wait wait. You mean the stakes were high. The risks are low.
I think he's just trying to sound cool.

The stakes weren't high. The stakes are what can happen to you, and the risk. The stakes and the risks are the same. The risk is the stake. Okay? Unless you're nicking meat from a butcher's, then the stakes are high and the risk is low. I don't know what the fuck you talking about, but what you meant was-
It was worth a risk
-the gain was high
The game was high.
Yeah
The game was high.
Yeah, the risk was low-
Yeah
-but it's not wasn't - it wasn't was it. Because 45p isn't a lot unless you are a kid.
It is when you're a kid.
It is when you're a kid.
Because I was getting 50 pence.
But then surely getting caught for nicking a Mars bar is higher when you're a kid.
No, it's not, look. You see, most of the time I didn't want to say which shop it was that I nicked it from, but it's where I did my paper round.
Ricky gasps
Now, the thing is-
So it's nicking from your own boss?
Ah But listen
I used to wake him up.
Oh! That is terrible.
But I helped him run... no because I...
This is awful. Go on. Hang on look I want to hear him.
That's really bad.
No I want to hear him rationalise his terrible crime.
Because that sweet old man. Used to give...
It's not an old man, I used to go around and wake him up. He hated running that place. If anything, I'd say I was his best asset.
Not really!
You were nicking from him!
I don't know how much he made on papers, but he'd probably got 45p profit. Oh, hold on.
They got their papers really early because I got up early.
Yeah, A Mars a day helps you work, rest and steal.
So I used to go round there, wake him up, he'd be like - "what are you doing round here so early?"
Ricky and Steve laugh.

"Dunno, I'm just hungry." - "what?" - "I'm just hungry for work" - "Oh well good boy. I'm just going to turn away a minute while you stand there in front of the confectionary. Uhm, I'll turn away now. And I've looked back and here's the papers. And thanks so much Karl because you're a lovely kid."
"You're such an honourable and trustworthy guy."
"I can't really afford to..."
"I've been betrayed so many times before. That's why my lovely wife is no longer with me. You know she went off with Ken."
Yeah. "At least I've got a friend. You turn up early..."
"At least I've got one young friend"
"You turn up early". Oh, God. It's brilliant. "Oh, and Karl, keep a look out 'cos"
"Someone's been nicking Mars bars"
"Yeah, I know it's not you, because I trust you implicitly. And by the way, Karl, why can you take a Mars bar for free?"
"Oh, thanks"
Well that never happened.
Stingey cunt...
So I'm getting 50 pence a day for delivering papers, but I needed the energy
Right
Now, if I spent my 50p on the Mars bar - 5p profit a day, it's not worth it.
No.
So... help yourself. I knew I was doing a good job for him.

No-no-no-no-no-no-no-no-no, not "So help yourself". That doesn't follow. "So help yourself". Get another job. Leave that job. Negotiate a pay rise. Not "Help yourself". That doesn't go, that's ridiculous. Where does it stop? If you're working a nuclear power plant? We're not paying me much. Have a bit of uranium.
Lovely little bit of Uranium?
Yeah. Yeah. That'll do.
It's a strange analogy, rick. Some [inaudible] straight from a bloke nicking stuff from work to he works in a powerplant and he's helping himself to a bit of uranium. What's he doing with uranium?!

Well. You know. Mars a day, and all that. And that's for energy. And so is uranium, but more energy than a Mars bar. Yeah. I never nicked. I never nicked because I couldn't bear the shame. Even the kid I knew that was shameful. I want a clear conscience. I want to go to bed and sleep at night, and I do Karl.
I haven't got restless leg syndrome or people shouting out my window. So I sleep at night because, I've got a clear conscience. And that, to me, is what guides me.

Well, it's like when I first moved to London and I was traveling - when I was living in Oval - I was traveling across London all the way to Shepherd's Bush every day. That's a big, long, 45 minutes, hour long journey. And there were not barriers at either end in those days. So I could get on the tube at one end and get off the other end and no one ever checked my ticket. I was buying tickets every day for months and months and months, and it was starting to seem to me weird I was like "No ones ever checking this". So of course, you know I got a little bit lazy, maybe. I stopped buying tickets occasionally taking the trip back and forth - ba-ba-ba-ba-boom - and then for maybe a month travelled without a ticket. And then I was coming up - kind of got bit blas. Obviously, coming up in an Oval station, someone steps up and says, "excuse me, can I see your ticket". And that's terrible because when you're in your mid 20s, it's not like a kid anymore. When you are an adult, you've made a reasoned decision there. You can't plead ignorance. So I said "Ahem Sorry?" - "Yeah do you - let me see a ticket, please". And I went "Yeah-yeh-yeh". So I was looking through because for some reason I used to keep a lot of old tickets. I was looking through, pretending to look for my ticket. I went "Oh, I don't know what's happened to it, but I did, actually. I bought one at Shepherd's Bush" and they went, "okay, if we phone up Shepherd's Bush and there's no evidence of you buying a ticket, you can go to prison. I'm going to ask you again. Have you got a ticket?"
"No"
Oh no. How embarrassing.
It was unbelievable
Being told off is the worst.

It's because there's people walking by and I'm being told off by a woman who is at least a foot and a half shorter than me, wearing a uniform, and it was so embarrassing. It was so cripplingly embarrassing.
Yeah

"Let me ask you again, have you got a ticket?" - "No, I haven't" - "So you lied" - "Yes, I did, yeah" - "Okay, were gonna have to take your details" But honestly, being told, and that's it, the shame. Maybe it's a good bit of upbringing, unlike Karl obviously, who's a man who's got no guilty conscience at all about the whole Mars Bar incident, but whereas you and I, Rick, were raised obviously by better parents, and we are - its been drummed into us.
How much was that train journey?
Ricky Laughs

You know we do feel that guilt and that's maybe one of the reasons why we don't transgress. This is an interesting - we talked earlier about the murder, thing. Of course, there's that sort of idea, which has often been used in films, in a godless universe, and if you do not feel guilt, what's to prevent you from committing murder? If you can get away with it. If you could commit to murder, let's say you wanted to, and you could get away with it, there is no one to judge you in a godless universe, and you can live with the guilt, what's to stop you doing it?

Well, I just like to say now, it is a godless universe, as an atheist, there is no God and I'm a good person, not because I want to get rewarded for it in heaven, because that's how I want to live my life, in a society that treats people like that. So a lot of the laws of the land, not just in England, in many countries, are from the Bible. I mean, that kicked it off. I mean, there was laws before, obviously, and there were different gods before this one, was invented, but let's have a look at the Ten Commandments.
Oh, yeah

I think that lays down most of the uh, a lot of them are good rules of thumb. We got to go along with them. They certainly didn't invent those, rules of thumb. I think that mankind were adhering to most of them before it - was handed down. So let's have a look at them. There's a website here, a Baptist Christian website forum. And this guy, maybe I shouldn't say his name, I mean, he's put it out there for public, but I don't want to embarrass him. He says, "Brethren and Sistren."

Ricky is reading from the Landover Baptist Church website [www.landoverbaptist.net/showthread.php?t=16785], a parody fundamentalist Baptist church he seemingly mistakes as legitimate. An example of "Poe's Law" - where without a clear indicator of the author's intent, any parodic or sarcastic expression of extreme views can be mistaken by some readers for a sincere expression of those views.
What? Never heard that before.
Yeah, I've learnt a word, brothers and sisters.
Could have said sisters.
Could have said people.
He could've said people, could've said folks.

"It has come to my attention that not only are many of our members unable to correctly recite all the Ten Commandments." It's probably a big problem. I don't know whether he goes around testing them, going, "Number Three? - Umm... - Get out! Go and learn it!", "but those who can remember, even a few, invariably get the sequence wrong"
Is that important?
Oh, well, it is. He says, "Let me set the record straight. The commandments do not come in a random sequence, with the exception of 7th commandment, an obvious anomaly."
Why?
Well, he reckons that thou shalt not commit adultery at number seven should really be 6th in terms of severity. Let me explain, "The commandments appear in order of severity"
Right

"The harsher the punishment, the closer to the top. I hope this handy color chart will make the intrinsic beauty of God's word more comprehensible to all." So this is it, he's laid it out. "Commandment Number One, Thou shalt have no other gods before me" Okay, "Alert level: Severe, Punishment: Genocide."
Whoa!

"Entire cities with men, women, children and animals must be killed", So that's a lovely, nice Christian view there. So if you worship another god before the right God, he doesn't name him by name, he just uses the term God.
Sure.
But there's only one, according to this.
Genocide.
Yeah, anyone who worship's another god. Genocide. Entire cities with men, women, children and animals must be killed. I don't know what the animals have ever done.
Ricky & Steve talk over each other
Thought the animals were fine. They're getting panicky.
Okay, so that's number one. That's the most severe. Worshiping the wrong God.
Sure.
Okay? Number two; thou shalt not make unto thee any craven image.
Okay. No craven images.
That's, I assume, druids, devil worshipers, anything like that, isn't it?
Er well, I think it's also just, I suppose it's kind of images that mock or degrade the Almighty.
Okay? Err.. severe.
What's the punishment there?
Genocide.
Genocide again?! Wow!
Genocide, that's his favorite there. Genocide. Entire cities with men, women, children and animals must be killed.
What worries me is we're a couple of smart guys and we're not entirely sure what that commandment means.
No.
So we could go but we could accidentally...
Yeah.
Three, thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain.
Okay.
Okay. I assume God made these, did he?
The lord?
He used the first three, talking about himself. Alert, level high. Capital punishment.
Just capital punishment? Not genocide thank God. Thank God!
No, No, No, you're just going to be put to death there. Not all your friends and family and dogs.
Sure.
Erm, leave the budgie! No!
Steve chuckles
Number four, remember the Sabbath day. Keep it holy. High.
So alert level high.
High yeah. Capital punishment death.
Capital punishment again, if you forget the holy day?!
Yeah. What makes me laugh is that sometimes you can be walking along and you go, "Oh, yeah, I'm just going to... Oh i keep thinking it's Monday". "You what?!"
Steve laughs
"You forgot it's Sunday?" "No I just...." "Ahhh... death."
Number five, honor thy father and thy mother. High.
Okay, so and if you don't honor your mother and...?
Capital punishment.
Capital punishment againnnn?!
A lot of death at the moment.
Againnnn capital punishment seems so strict!
Yeah, yeah, we haven't even got to thou shalt not kill yet. And yet he's killed everyone so far.
Wow, jeeze.
Now, seven, he's put a number six here. He's put him out of order six and seven, because he thinks this is higher. Thou shalt not commit adultery. High. Capital punishment.
Capital punishment again!

Now, the fella who did this website. He's put Thou shalt not commit adultery above thou shalt not kill. God had it the other way around, thou shalt not kill. But this fella, I reckon his wife played away
Steve laughs
Right, right. Yeah.

I'm putting them in a different order, because before let's see, number six, he's put Thou shalt not kill. Alert level elevated. Capital punishment in some cases. So if you murder someone, you can sometimes be killed. If you commit adultery, always death.
Always get killed.
So I think he's made that he can have his wife put to death, right? Or he could kill her, but maybe get off with it.
Right, wow.
That's why he's done that. Number eight, thou shalt not steal. Guarded. Excessive fines only in rare cases capital punishment.
Oh just excessive fines?
Yeah, excessive.
Number nine, thou shalt not bear false witness to thy neighbor. So basically lying. Low. Despisement and scorn.
Is that the punishment?
Yeah. For lying? Yeah. Despisement and scorn, yeah.
Dispisement and scorn...
Thou shalt not covet, really.
Don't covet stuff...
Don't try and get stuff, don't be jealous of stuff and try and get it.
Punishment?
Despisement and scorn.
Despisement and scorn. Sure.

So I'm going to go through, just going to go down these, see which ones I commit. Thou shalt have no other God. I don't have any God, so I haven't broken that one. Two, craven images. No, I don't have any craven. I don't accept there's a God to three. Thou shalt not take the name of Lord in vain. Again, I don't take his name in vain because I don't believe he exists. So I'm fine there. Remember the Sabbath - I always remember Sunday. I've got a calendar and everything. Honour thy father.
Yeah, I do that. Never commit adultery. Don't do that.
Never killed anyone?
No, never killed anyone. Don't steal. I don't lie and I don't covet. So I am an amazing Christian.
Yeah, you're pretty clean living guy.
Wow. There you go.
Well, whereas I don't know, Karl, have you ever... what's your view?
Still open, like, post that isn't for me.

Oh, just going to see if that's on there. That's, opening other people's post alert level: Low, punishment embarrassment. You have to walk along with your trousers around your ankle saying "I'm a div".
Why do you open other people's mail?

It's just a fellow called Bruce who used to bloke who used to own the flat before me. And I don't know, I started off and I thought we should have pass it on, because when people move, it's a lot of messing about, tracking down where they've gone. So I thought I should have just leave them for a bit and collected some for a bit. And then there was one that sort of said, this is important on the front of it. So I thought, how important is it? So I opened it.
Was it important?
Not really. It was from the tattooists.
Ricky laughs.
What did they say?
It was just something about a...
"Oh we used the AIDS needle on you, can you come in for a little test."
So I just started that just kind of though oh I'll start opening it - having a look. And it was weird because, do you know like how you get fed up of being yourself?
No, but go on, I'm intrigued.
Of course.
You can just have days where you like...
I wish I was Brad Pitt.
Well you know.
Bruce Willis in your case isn't it?

Well, this bloke was Bruce, so I just go let's see what- if I was Bruce, would I be happy of being him? You know, like I've said to you before, you never know if you don't feel well, because they can't put you in someone else's body to sort of compare.
No, most people can just use their imagination.
Yeah, sure.
So I sort of think...
They don't actually need to physically go to someone else's body to understand that.
Yeah, like ghost. Yes, exactly.
So I think, well, would I enjoy being Bruce more?
Sure.
What have you gleamed from Bruce? He's got a tattoo - we know that.
There wasn't that much. He's mainly busy at Christmas. A lot of Christmas cards, which were good because I don't get that many.
Yeah
You put up his Christmas cards?
Pop them up.
You put up his Christmas cards...
Thats-
You had Christmas cards hanging in your flat - "Have a lovely Christmas Bruce - Auntie Jean"
Yeah...
That's crazy!
Hang on a minute!

Because when you put them on, you know, your mantlepiece or your shelf, or whatever. You're not, you're not looking in them every day. It's just a picture of Father Christmas, It don't matter who it's to or from.
Well why have them up at all?
Well why not just buy some blank-
It's something christmassy.
You can just buy some blank cards and put them up!
Use them every year!
I don't have to, Bruce has got a lot of friends!
Yeah but...

It was more awkward, right, because the bloke downstairs because I always collect the stuff for Bruce. I got talking to a bloke who's in the same block, and he used to see me picking stuff up for Bruce. He'd always say, 'Alright Bruce.'
No!
You never told him that you're not Bruce.
No. No point.
In a pub I used to drink in, the landlord got into his head that I was Steve.
You don't mean me.
No, no, no.
You just mean he was called Steve.

Exactly. Before I met you. This was Twenty... Five years ago. And he called me Steve. And it got to the point I couldn't correct him because it would have been embarrassing for him. And so after about two years, we were playing cards and someone said, Ricky. And he went, who's? Ricky? And I went, Ricky? And I just went, red. What do you mean, Ricky? I went, yeah, that's my name. He said, what do you mean, fucking Ricky? And I look, Steve. I went, no, it's not Steve. He said, Well, I've been calling you Steve for two years. I went, have you? Like denied I ever heard him call me Steve. Oh, this guy, right? He um,
Wait hang on, what happened, what was the follow up of it?

He was sorta like, he was a bit confused. And then I think he still called me Steve for a little while, but sometimes it was Ricky, sometimes Steve, it was fine. But this guy, right, he was a bank robber, okay?
Really?

Yeah. He'd done 17 years in all in prison. And I was a bit scared of him. I'm fascinated. He was fine. He was done. Now he'd gone straight, totally straight. And he was running his pub. And I remember once he told me stories about it, he'd go on about it- and he did it with four people and they all did time. And he said he said, but you wouldn't recognize them now. He said, they are the most respectful people you'd ever seen. He said, yeah, they're just lovely businessmen. High of sophistication now. You'd never guess. And then one day he came over to his busy pub. He went, Rick, steve. He said, you know those geezers I did the job with? I did this time with the other three. I said, they are in the pub here now. See if you can guess who they are. So you can never guess who they are. I looked around. I saw three blokes in sheepskin coats with tinted hair covered in gold sovereigns and gold necklaces. And I went, no. He went those three. I went, you are joking. You are fucking joking. That was his idea of total sophistication and tinted beards. But they look like fat Bee Gees covered in gold and sheepskin. It was unbelievable. That is a surprise. That is a surprise. I thought they were barristers. Oh, unbelievable.
I was always terrified of being mugged, when I first moved to London.
Um, and you remember, Rick, I had, uh, a wallet with all my stuff in, and then I took to carrying a fake wallet-
It's lovely.

-which had some sort of old library cards and DVD cards - you know - video shop cards and stuff, and like I put a fiver in there, you know. And then I got really anxious because I thought, what if I hand over my fake wallet? And he goes, well, it's a fake wallet, okay? Then I got hand over the real wallet, but maybe he also punishes me, you know. He takes it out on me because he's angry. So then I took to carrying a second fake wallet. So I spent about two months carrying three wallets around.
Ricky wheezes and giggles

Two of which were fake. Right? And then, do you know the reason I stopped? Because I thought, what if he-I give him both fake wallets? I give him one fake wallet, he opens it, he goes, well, this is fake wallet. I give him the second fake wallet. He's now, he's going to be twice as angry as he would have been if he only had the one fake wallet. And then I was thinking, what-but what if I do give him the fake wallet? And then he just starts using the library cards and the video cards, you know, you could run up a huge fine.
Yeah.
I'd be-
Yeah.
I'm in the same position-
You're worse off-
-were it have been I had given him the money.
Yeah I also, I don't believe you'd ever put a fiver in the fake wallet-
Nonononono.
-you'll be willing to -- yeah, yeah.
I had a run-in with crime. I was, uh, ripped off-
Really?
-in a- in a big sting operation, a few years ago. Um, I was at home and I was just - I was rushing out and uh, the phone went, and it was my bank.
Yeah.
And they went "Is that Mr. Gervais?" And I went "Yeah", He went um, "Have you recently bought 200,000 worth of gold bullion?"
Steve giggles
And I went um, I went "Jane! Have we, have we 'de-bought, are we bought 200-" She went, "What?", "Have we bought 200,000 worth of gold bullion?", "No course not." I went "No."
"Oh um, well someone's uh, taking that money out of your bank account, uh, fraudulently, and uh, they've purchased gold."

And I went, "Right. Okay." They went um, "We'd like your permission to get the CID involved." I went "well, yeah." I said, "of course". I said, "but hold on, you know, it wasn't me then, um, so do I get the money back?"
And they went, "Yeah, y- all the money will be, um, put back into your bank account."
I went "Fine." I said "Yeah." I basically went "Yeah. Fill your boots."

And they went, "Um and can you come down? I went, "Oh, yes.", so I arranged the time. I went down to the bank, there was the CID there, waiting. And uh, what it turned out it was sort of an inside job, someone who did some sort of random, um, checking of facts. You know when they phone you up, and say are you happy with the service. They put down the phone and went, "Oh, you'll never guess who I spoke to, that, Ricky Gervais.
Right, right.
And um, someone overheard. They were involved. They've got a payoff from Mr. Big somewhere, that was out of the country.
But that- Isn't there more, I mean you can't just- even if you work in a bank, you can't just walk off with cash. Can you? There must've been a more elaborate-

Yeah. They did a transaction, didn't they? They okayed the transaction like it was me, for these people, and then these people bought gold with it, and now all they have to do is go and collect the gold. Now this is the tricky bit. So, what they don't know is now the bank know, that it's not me collecting it. So whoever turns up for the gold, they said they're probably just be- they might even be innocent couriers.
Yes.
But then we get, you know the go, the go-betweens or whatever.
Where is gold bullion kept?

I don't know. I suppose you go and get it from a, vault somewhere and take it away and take delivery of it. I don't know if it literally changes hands, or not. So what they need is obviously my passport. So they got the people. So it was going to go to court. I didn't have to go to court, but I had to meet with the CID for all the details and take that - it wasn't me - and all that. So the funny thing was, I'm there with the CID man and I said, well, how did they think they were going to get away with it? And they said, well, they turn up with them a fake passport of yours, show the ID, and I walk away. I went "right, okay". And they said "they get a passport from either a dead man or they steal one and they replace it with your details and your picture". And the CID man started smirking. The picture they used was this one. And he showed me this fake passport. And I'll tell you what, I was laughing. Then he started chuckling and we laughed about ten minutes, because all they did was, they cut out the picture on the first series of The Office from the DVD. So it's a picture of David Brent sitting behind the desk with that little smug look on his face. That's my passport in this thing. So, I mean, they might have got caught. Anyway.
It's nice to know that even such elaborate operations as this, it still comes down to just Idiocy criminal incompetence who.
Was left in charge, where they go, Dave, you're doing so and so. Julie, you're on the inside. Bertie, can you get a picture?
Yes.
You can get a photograph of Bricky jails, can you?
Yes.
Right, okay. What are you going to HMV for? What are you going to HMV for?
I knew we shouldn't have recruited someone who looks exactly like Bernard Bresslaw.
Karl have you ever been conned?
There's always someone doing well on me. There's always someone - if I go - if they're a little bit short, go round to Pilkington's.

But three or four times a day, sometimes I call him up and he goes, Right, the washing machine's broke and they came around, they've done this right, they couldn't fix it, but they would call it charged 90 quid. I called them back and they said, no, they can't do that. Turns out they can't do it. It's like a string of things where it looks like Karl's handing out money like the end of a comic book. He goes, and that's for the broken window and there's for my sausages. It's like a queue of people just making money off Karl.
They're normally all right if I'm face to face with them.
Really?
Yeah. I can go in a place where a lot of stuff now is done on the phone. It's all phone innit? Because no one's - it's all over the world where you're speaking to these people.
Yeah.

I was talking to someone the other day about the alarm system in the flat, called them up, thought, I will be good to get this going again. Have an alarm system. Haven't had one for years. I might as well use it, it's there. So I called them up and said, yeah, there's an alarm system in this flat I bought. When I get it going again, what's the situation? So they took a load of details and stuff and they said, Right, what you have to do, it's 400 quid a year - I said "what?" - It's a 400 quid a year. I said "What's that for?" - he said, "if the alarm goes off, we can guarantee that a copper will be there in, like, a minute and a half". I said, "I don't want that, I'm just happy with the alarm just going off. I'll give the key to the neighbour". No, you can't do that. You've got to have this way. I said "400..." - I said "I thought alarms are meant to stop you being robbed". "You what sir?" - doesn't understand sarcasm.

Yeah. Just to get out your system, when you know you've been conned, you just laugh in the face of adversity. I remember, um, it was, um, a couple of days before Christmas. I was going away, but I had a dripping tap and it started dripping more, so, uh, there was nothing I could do. The maintenance people were away, the caretaker's away, I couldn't get in a--. So, I uh, I called out an emergency plumber. I knew this was going to cost, but bloke came round. Honestly, he made you look smart. He was like one of those kids who looked like a lumpy child. He was probably 20-
Yeah.
--but he just looked like - you know what I mean? -
Yeah
--they'd scaled up a sort of 13 year old big faced lad.
Yeah, yeah.

Right? He went "Alright?" And he came in and uh, he didn't know how to stop it. He couldn't unscrew it. He went, "I don't know what to do." I called my brother, he's there just- I said, "Uh, Bob, what can I do?" He said, "You could crush the pipe and then get it cut and fixed when you got..." I said, "Great idea." So I said to the plumber, I said, "Can we crush the pipe?" "Oh, yeah, I'll go and get a tool." He went down the van, came up with this thing, like a fat sort of little pair of pliers. He couldn't- he wasn't strong enough, so I went, [Sighs] I had a go. I said, "How about we both do it?" So we both put our hands on it and we managed to crush the pipe, flatten the pipe, cut it off. He put a little thing on the end of it so it wouldn't leak, eh? I went, "Great." Uh, I said, uh, "How much is that?" He went "180 quid." So I went, "Right, okay." So I wrote him out a cheque for 180 quid and I thought I'll have a bit of sarcasm. So it wasn't his idea, I helped him do it. I went, "How much was that tool?" He went, "[Sighs] About a fiver." I went, "That's paid for itself innit?"
[Steve laughs]
Silence - he went, "Yep." Just nothing. Just nothing. Tough crowd. Right?
Yeah, of course.
So I signed the cheque, and he went, "[Sighs]" he said, "I forgot to charge you for the little washer on the end." I went, "How much is that?" He went, "2.50." I went, "Can I give you that in cash?"
[Steve laughs]

"I written--" He went "Yeah." I went, "There you go, there's- there's the 2.50 for the washer on the end and there's the 180." And he went and that was it. I didn't even get a little chuckle. He didn't even think... He should've gone, "Well, let's split that because we both did that."
Yeah.
"Yeah, that's 90 quid each." I go, "Okay, yeah, that's brilliant mate. Cheers. Here's a Christmas bonus."
[Steve laughs]

I have, uh, a fascinating tale to tell you, Karl. I think you'll be intrigued. Um, when I do, um, junkets for films in, in, America or, uh, Toronto Film Festival, um I was assigned a security. And uh, I've had security before, often have security, they just sort of get you in and out of the car and- usually just to control sort of autograph hunters and things and... But um, this time I was given a security and he came in a suit. He was about 30, he looked quite unassuming. I thought he was from a, just a security firm and there was a couple of them and uh, first of all, they were talking to each other and I thought, "Well, the stakes are higher here, I don't know why." And uh, they drove us to the hotel and there was  uh, loads of people going into the hotel. I mean, much bigger stars than me, you know? There was Ed Norton and- and George Clooney and they were going in and out. And he goes, "I- we can go past these." And he called ahead and he knew everyone, he just knew everyone. And we went down in the car park. We were met by another security guard in the hotel that let us go past everyone. I mean, Clooney's having to queue up and sign. I'm thinking, "This is weird." And I was feeling bit guilty because I was there to promote the film and I think, "This security guard is so good, I'm never going to ever have to bump into anyone." It was amazing.
[Steve laughs]

And he were there the next day and he took us to the junket and back and he put us on the thing and then it turned out that, uh, he was actually LAPD, who was doing this for celebrities 'cause he earned more money. And then um, I found out I had a gun. He said, "I can't come in the airport with you, I can't take my gun." So... he's armed. So I've got a security who's LAPD, who's- who's armed. And I'm fascinated now, I'm fascinated. This man is walking around with me with a little earpiece, talking to everyone, he seems to know everyone, and he's got a gun. I think, "This is amazing." Then one night he said, uh, he dropped me off at the hotel and he said, "Uh, I've actually been called. I've got to go on a mission. They need my help." I said, "What is it?" He said, "It's a hostage situation," he said, "And I'm, I'm also SWAT." So now I'm just- this is amazing. He's now officially the coolest man I've ever met in my life. So he goes off. Then I'm thinking and I'm worried about him. And I was talking to Jane, I was thinking, "Wow, he does this to get some extra cash, he's risking his life, and now he's going to a hostage situation." And I was thinking, "Oh God, it's just- he's just a silent hero."
Mm.
So next day he comes up, I said, "How was it?" He said, "Oh it was fine," he said, "I just turned up," he said, "I had to- I had to do it in my suit," he said, uh, "'cause I'm the negotiator."
What?
So now he's an armed security guard. Who's in LAPD, a special SWAT, and he's one of nine negotiators, in LA. We're in LA now. We'd come from Toronto. We went via New York, in LA.
So I went, oh my God. And I just asked him questions-
Mmm.
-for 2 hours.

Um, so first thing that happens is, so someone runs in with a hostage. This guy who's just a kid who was 19. He'd done a robbery, he panicked and he'd ran away. The police were after him, he ran in and he took his-his kid with him. It was just a three-year-old kid, okay? Um, that often happens. Uh most hostages that people take are their family 'cause it's all they've got. And they go, I want to kill my wife or my kid, and that. And they don't mean it. They're not going to. But they need, they need a hostage. They've got a gun.

So he talks to them and he says things to him like, "You know, you didn't mean this to happen, did you?" And they went "No no, I just-" he said "they got out of hand. It just got out of hand." And he has to let them trust him because they-they've got hatred for the police, of course. They don't trust the police and that.
And um.
The first thing he does, is call the phone company and say, "What's the number of this address?", he goes, "Change it by one digit."

So now only he can call that number, 'cause of course, you can't have an engaged signal. If they haven't got a phone, they have to throw a phone through a window. So they've got to have contact with this guy.
Mmm.
You know? I said um, what happens if uh this guy says, "Ah you're never going to get me out. I'm going to kill all the hostages"? He said, "Then my sole purpose is to get him to stand near a window."

And I went, "Wow". Now apparently there's a police marksman ready of course. If they think they've lost him, the important thing is you've got to take him out because he's got to protect the innocent. So how they shoot 'em is they shoot 'em in the top lip and it takes out the brain stem so there's no reflex and I'm just being absolutely-
Mmm.
-I'm captivated. What do you think of that Karl, as a job? It's amazing, isn't it?
Uhm
Yeah. I mean, once you've done one, though, it's like any job, innit I 'spose?
Yeah.
Once you've done one.
Yeah.
Bor--
Not impressed?
Boring.
No, it's good and uh--
Could you do it? Do you reckon you could do it? Do you reckon you could negotiate someone out of a hostage situation?
Well, I think in one of them things. There's nothing you can do. It's like - it doesn't matter if it goes wrong because-
Well, it does.
-you did your bit. No, it's like being a vet innit.
Not really, not really, 'cause - that's a ridiculous thing to say
No, it's nothing, it's nothing like being a vet.
No, it is. What I mean is, you're-you're expected to-
No no no.
-make a little kitten live.

No no no. There's loads of -- because I was saying. So he says, I need a car by five o'clock or I'm going to kill someone. He then makes sure that he doesn't kill anyone, but he makes sure that car doesn't come till quarter past five.
Mmm.

Even if it's there. He keeps going, it's on its way because then the hostage knows that, he's not in control, really. Even if it's as easy as saying, I want my wife here, and you can get her there at five-
(unintelligible)
-you make sure she doesn't turn up till twenty past five.
Yeah.
It's just little things like that that's just absolutely fascinating. The psychology of it is just amazing.
But he's not bothered, is he? If he's 15 minutes late?
He is bothered. He is 'cos he empathizes with these guys and he says, "no, you've got to understand".
No but the fella' in the house with the gun.
Yeah
He's not going anywhere, 15 minutes, either side doesn't matter. Well, why is he in a rush?
I don't think Karl's getting how important.
I'm not sure he is
You said, you said...
Yeah
They make the car 15 minutes late.
Yeah
He's getting his car, that blocks not in a rush.
He's never going to get in the car, is he? That's the other thing as well, because once a bloke said to him, I need a car, and he just went "where are you going to go?"

And the bloke went, "errr yeah forget that". He has to make them forget their deadlines and their demands so soon It doesn't matter. He has to get in their head. But to do that, he says that he has to empathize with them to a certain extent. He has to understand why they're doing it, to talk to them and go, yeah, you've had a bad day. That would send anyone, but he has to get their trust. Karl, try and talk me out. You think it's that easy. Right, I've got a host situation, I've done a crime. I've run in the building. They go, there's only one person we can ask for. Get me Karl Pilkington. Okay? You turn up, right? What's your questions.
You've asked me to deal with this.

No no no no, the police know that you're their top man. There's a guy in here, he's got a gun, he's got a hostage, okay? He's just done a crime. They don't know what to do. Okay? Right. You turn up. What's your first question to them?
I'm talking to you?
Well no you've got to access...
Right, I'd say, I'd say, Right. Errrrr I think there's a saying, actually. You say "where's Brass?" I found that out. I heard that. I overheard that.
What's that?
It was something...
You're wasting time. Whose that bald cunt whose just turned up? I'm gonna fucking kill..
Listen, Right where's brass?
What does it mean?
I heard it at school
I don't know, the fuck you talking about
You can't just use
It means, I heard someone use it... it means the top person of the police who were around at the moment.
I'm the fucking top brass here. I've got a fucking gun against this kid's head. Who are you you bald little shithead. Where's my car?
What car?
I've asked for a car. Where's my fucking car? Am I talking to you now? Am I?
If you want.
Are you the negotiator?
Yeah.
Right, get me a fucking car.
Where'd you want to go?
I'm fucking sore for shouting through the window. Throw a phone through the window so I can talk to you over the phone.
No. All right, in a minute.
Don't ever fucking say no to me.
In a minute, I said.
Okay.
Right the clocks going. Where's this fucking phone?
Listen.
I've got a sore throat...
Just hang on a moment...
I've got a sore throat, I can't talk anymore.
I've been called up here.
I can't hear you.
I've been called up here.
Yeah. Can you put the phone through? Why are you putting the phone through? You dopey cunt, you want to talk to him.
Because I don't want to give you a phone straight away. You said you've got to delay him.
No, you've got to talk to them. You shouldn't even demand a phone. You should make sure you've got a phone, you dopey twak.
Give him a phone.
Right, thanks. Alright how's it going?
"All right?"
Who are you, by the way? Who are you?
Bruce?
"I can't give you them details."
Well, you can, because I've got to trust you, you dopey sod. Are you police, or just some fucking cunt walking by?
"I'm a policeman."
"Right. I don't trust policemen."
"No, but I'm a bit higher than that."
Ricky and Steve Laugh
"So, listen..."
"Don't you tell me - I'm laying down the law here."
"No, Listen - "
"I'm going to shoot someone unless I get a fast car. I've done a robbery, it's all gone wrong, but I want a car to the airport, I want a plane standing by."
"You don't know me, but I do this a lot, alright? And I can tell you that it never works out, right? Do you know anyone who's done what you're doing and who's now living a happy life?"
"Well, I don't care. I don't care about living anyway. I don't care about living up. I don't care if this goes wrong because I'm going to shoot the hostage - "
What's your problem?
Ricky and Steve Laugh
I think you've got the wrong attitude, mate. I think you've got the wrong attitude 'ere.
"No, but this is, to be honest with you, this was my last week."
Why are you telling him that?
Because I want to bring him down to my level.
Right. "What's that got to do with it?"
"Well, you know, I've done this job for a long time."
"Right"
"Sometimes I felt like you, even though I'm on this side, you know, sometimes I feel like, Oh, I've had enough of this."

"Well, I have had enough. But I'll tell you, I don't care about living or dying here, so if I don't get a car to the airport, all bets are off, I'm killing everyone and then myself. So you'll be a big loser. You will be a big loser, son." There you go, I given you the clue now, Karl. He doesn't care about getting away with it. Now, you've got to get him to stand near a window. You've got to take him out, because I've got a gun to someone's head, you can't burst in, right? Come on. How do you get him to stand near a window?
"Ohh, I bet you're hot in there."
Keep it going, keep going.
"I am, I am hot, that's why I've just drawn the curtain and keeping away from the window, because the sun's blazing and it's not too bad away from the window."
"It's uhhh, the sun's going round the back now, just come and have a look. It's a lovely, lovely, evening."
"Why did you want me to stand near a window?"
"I think just because when you see how nice an evening it is... "
It's the worst, worst, load of drivel ever. It's the worst -
"When you see how..." Keep going, I'm interested, "When you see how lovely an evening it is"
No, it's that thing, that thing, "I've heard that if you smile, you feel better. So have a little smile. Think of a happy moment in your life."
I'll tell you what a happy moment in my life would be. Putting a bullet through your little round head, you cunt!"
"Keep thinking about that image"
Right?
"And you can see that round head. Just come to the window, I'll show you the round head."
That would probably work, actually.
Yeah [Ricky Laughs] "No, I'm not going to come near the window. You come near the window. You come near my window, up you come. Are you coming near the window?"
"No, not yet." Delaying it again. "Right, I'm coming near the window."
Well, I'm going to shoot you if you come near the window. You dopey prat.
Well why? I thought we were getting somewhere here.
No, I'm going to shoot you. I've conned you. I've negotiated you to come near the window and I'm going to shoot you in the head. You prat.
I'll just leave, then.

Well, that's about it. I hope you enjoyed the Ricky Gera's Guide to Law and Order. And the next one in the series is The Ricky Gervais's Guide to the Future, which is out on the 29 December. So, look forward to that. Anyway, it's goodbye from me, Ricky Gervais, Steven Merchant.
Goodbye.
And Karl Pilkington.
Aight.

synopsis.description: Karl has no opinion on Law and Order.
Karls used to nick Mars bars from a sweet old man
Steve gets caught by a train conductor
Karl opens post that isn't for him.
Karl puts up Bruce's Christmas cards

trivia.description: Bernard Bresslaw was a British actor and comedian. He was best known as a member of the Carry On film franchise.
